title: Big Bang Theory gets shout out by winners of actual Nobel Prize Awards
text:
Sheldon has been recognised with a nod at the real life Nobel Prize ceremony (Picture: Michael Yarish/CBS via Getty Images)

The Big Bang Theory finally made its way to the real Nobel Prize ceremony on Tuesday evening – just a few months after Sheldon Cooper earned his own in the series finale.

Sheldon (played by Jim Parsons) and his wife Amy Farrah-Fowler (Mayim Bialik) were seen receiving their long-coveted prize as the show bid farewell after 12 years as a much-loved sitcom.

So it seems only fitting that the show become an official part of the Nobel Prize world with a tiny nod by the academy team at the Nobel Prize presentation in Stockholm, Sweden.

Academy member Ulf Danielsson took inspo from the show’s theme song, sung by Barenaked Ladies, and started the evening’s events by declaring: ‘Our whole universe was in a hot, dense state, then nearly 14 billion years ago expansion started.’

It seemed to fit into the evening’s winners and their achievements in physics, as three scientists took home the award for their work around the understanding of the actual Big Bang, as the discovery of a planet outside of our solar system.

Secretary general of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, Goran Hansson, also praised the show, and called it a ‘fantastic achievement’ for bringing the ‘world of science to laptops and living rooms around the world.’

He said: ‘I hope that Sheldon and Amy are not too disappointed today.’

Somehow, we reckon that they would be more than pleased with their recognition.

The final episode of the show, titled The Stockholm Syndrome, was credited as the show’s best ever episode by fans and IMDb ratings.

The 279th episode overall saw Sheldon ditch his years planned speech belittling those that doubted him for a sentimental speech to his friends, praising them for their help in getting them to where he was.

The cast – completed by Kunal Nayyar (Raj), Melissa Rauch (Bernadette), Simon Helberg (Howard), Kaley Cuoco (Penny) and Johnny Galecki (Leonard), in tears as they listened to Sheldon’s speech, and as the usually headstrong character finally acknowledged what he’d been ignoring for 12 years.

‘I was under a misapprehension that my accomplishments were mine alone. nothing can be further from the truth,’ he announced.

‘I have been encouraged, sustained, inspired and tolerated not only by my wife but by the greatest group of friends anyone had ever had.’

The Big Bang Theory is available to stream on Netflix in the UK.
